instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message:
[FONT=Helvetica Neue]820- 2532[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue] [/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue]slightl liquid residue on bottom of board between ports and fan, cleaned[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue] [/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue]powers on but no chime/post, randomly/intermittently every 8th time or so will turn on and work, but on restart not guaranteed to work again, once truly warmed up will usually be able to restart and be stable[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue] [/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue]replaced the poly-tants as Louis recommends (usually its <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> causing the problem on this model):[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue] [/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue]<CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7660</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C9510</CAPACITOR>[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue] [/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue]now[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue]<SIGNAL>P1V05S5_LL</SIGNAL> reading 1.2V should be 1.05V[/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue] [/FONT]
  [FONT=Helvetica Neue]any ideas on possible culprits?[/FONT]

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message:
did you replace the poly-tant,
or did you place a bigger 330UF ????

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message: Usually some corrosion on CPU vcore regulator <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> on the edge of the board. Look close! Those little holes where something travels from one side of the board to another.

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message:
no definitely no spill that far over next to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, all of it was between fans and the ports, <CHIP>U3700</CHIP> to <CHIP>U9500</CHIP>.  i'm waiting for some 22uf to arrive to try a few more.

i replaced with standard cap where i could and unfortunately by new poly-tant on what i couldn't find/afford easily

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message:
You have liquid damaged board and are replacing caps....Logic would say something is corroded, this is not a cap problem. 
When the machine does not boot, are all voltages present especially CPU Vcore?

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message:
[SIZE=12px]so [/SIZE]     [SIZE=12px]<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is reading .99V instead of 1.25V [/SIZE]
[FONT=Courier]CPU is getting warm[/FONT]
[SIZE=12px]which brings me to the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> circuit where I was already thinking of doing the poly tants  [/SIZE][FONT=Courier]<CAPACITOR>C7117</CAPACITOR>[/FONT][FONT=Courier] and [/FONT][FONT=Courier]<CAPACITOR>C7155</CAPACITOR> 

i've never worked on this circuit before, going to watch some more rossman vids, any other suggestions/ tips?[/FONT]

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message: .99V on CPU is fine, it is a dynamic voltage set by CPU. This could be anything, corrosion somewhere under some chip. Only you saw where the corrosion was.....

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message: Also fine. The corrosion was not there....

threads.title: 820- 2532 not posting (not normal poly-tant problem)
threads.message:
really not sure where to start, guess i'm going to have to go thru and measure every line and hope something shows up weird, powers on and fans run high but no post.

there was residue but almost no corrosion.  only real corrosion was around some USB caps (<CAPACITOR>C4605</CAPACITOR>, L4605 and <CAPACITOR>C9480</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C9481</CAPACITOR>), I was getting 4.2V there, cleaned and now getting full 5V and 3.3V.
only other stuff that whatever liquid it was touched was the main ISL and <CAPACITOR>C9590</CAPACITOR>, realtek ethernet, and that whole firewire stuff next to it

any suggestions, i was assuming it had to be cpu, gpu or ram since it did post a few times, now i'm no longer getting any post no matter how many times i try
